text: Which of the following groups of animals do not possess a nervous system?
explanation: Porifera are 'pore bearing' organisms, commonly known as sponges, are the only multicellular organisms without a nervous system. Their response to stimuli is by a contraction in their bodies.

text: The structural similarities in Paramecium and Euglena are in the

options.C: presence of micro and mega nuclei in both
options.D: presence of anterior and posterior contractile vacuoles

text: Which of the following organisms cannot exist freely on its own?
explanation: The plasmodium is a single-celled parasite that multiplies in red blood cells of humans as well as in the mosquito intestine. Hence, it doesn't live freely.

text: Which of the following cell organelles is the site for the production of ATP?
explanation: The production of ATP happens in the mitochondrion, which likewise exists in both animals and plants.

text: An example of osmosis in plants is the

options.A: movement of water through the xylem
options.B: loss of water vapour from the stomata
options.C: translocation of food through the phloem
options.D: absorption of water from the soil by the root

explanation: Osmosis is responsible for the ability of plant roots to draw water from the soil. Plants concentrate solutes in their root cells by active transport, and water enters the roots by osmosis.

text: The organism that can carry out both autotropic and heterotrophic modes of nutritions is
explanation: Euglena use their chloroplasts to produce nutrients through photosynthesis. It is a dual organism as it can act both as an autotroph, making its own food, and heterotroph, feeding on other substances.

text: The diagram above illustrates a part of the human skeleton. It represents the bones of the
explanation: The diagram shows the lower arm which can be seen between the elbow and the wrist.

text: Which of the labelled parts of the diagram of the part of the human skeleton articulates with the head of the trochlea to form a hinge joint?
explanation: The part II is attached to the humerus. It forms a hinge joint to make up the hand.

text: The diagram above illustrates a part of the human skeleton. The labelled part that provides surface for the attachment of the triceps is
explanation: The triceps is a large muscle on the back of the upper limb of many vertebrates. The part III is a part of the bone that forms the triceps.

text: The diagram above illustrates the transverse section of a
explanation: The diagram shows the transverse section of a dicotyledonous stem showing its tissue distribution.

text: Which of the following actions does not occur during exhalation in man?

options.D: Air pressure increases in the thoracic cavity

explanation: When you breathe in, or inhale, your diaphragm tightens and moves downward (flattens).

text: The diagram above is an illustration of the urinary tubule in a mammal. Which of the following substances is found in the part labelled II only?
The diagram above is an illustration of the urinary tubule in a mammal. The part which contains lowest concentration of urea is labelled
The diagram above is an illustration of the urinary tubule in a mammal. Which of the following substances is greater in concentration in the part labelled IV when compared to that part labelled I?
Deamination of amino acids in the liver produces
Which of the following glands also serves as an exocrine gland?
explanation: The liver and pancreas are both exocrine and endocrine glands; they are exocrine glands because they secrete products—bile and pancreatic juice—into the gastrointestinal tract through a series of ducts, and endocrine because they secrete other substances directly into the bloodstream.

text: Which of the following sequences is the correct route of the transmission of impulses along a reflex arc?

options.A: \(Receptor\to sensory neuron \to synapse \to intermediate neuron \to synapse \to motor neuron \to effector\)
options.B: \(Receptor \to motor neuron \to synapse \to intermediate neuron \to synapse \to sensory neuron \to effector\)
options.C: \(Effector \to intermediate neuron \to synapse \to motor neuron \to synapse \to sensory neuron \to receptor\)
options.D: \(Effector \to motor neuron \to synapse \to sensory neuron \to synapse \to intermediate neuron \to receptor\)

text: Which of the following groups of organisms do not have members that can be called autotrophs?

options.A: Efficiency of energy transfer between trophic levels can be studied
options.B: Comparisons of pyramids for different ecosystems can be made
options.C: More accurate comparisons of trophic levels

text: Which of the following materials is not easily biodegradable?
Which of the following pairs of organisms is in a mutualistic relationship?
The establishment of game reserves and parks is a method of
Which of the following practices is not used in conserving water?
Which of the following resources cannot be renewed?
The type of variation illustrated above is
explanation: The rolling of the tongue is an example of discontinuous variation. This type of variation describes traits that fall into distinct categories, with no intermediates. In the case of tongue rolling, individuals are either able to roll their tongue or they are not. There's no "partial rolling".

text: Which of the following characters is not a morphological variation?
An apple plant can produce sexually and asexually and it has 40 chromosomes in its leaf cells. How many chromosomes would be in each gamete and somatic cell?

options.A: 20 chromosomes in the gametes and 10 in the somatic cells
options.B: 40 chromosomes in the gametes and 20 in the somatic cells
options.C: 20 chromosomes in the gametes and 40 in the somatic cells
options.D: 40 chromosomes in the gametes and 40 in the somatic cells

text: Assuming that A is the gene for normal skin color and is dominant, while a is the gene for albinism and its recessive, what is the likely genotype of the couple which had 50% normal and 50% albino offspring?
explanation: Crossing Aa & aa  would give 50% normal and 50% albino offspring

options.C: The members dwell in the same habitat
